comment.narrative:
1. As to the latest data available at The Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI) project website (update for 2021), Uzbekistan currently ranked 15,87 in Control of Corruption Index that is progress compared to 14,90 in previous year and close to target for 2021 (16).
2. The 2021 became the breakthrough year in terms of promoting corruption proofing of legislation and regulatory in public administration. By the initiative of the Ministry of Justice, the Decree of the President (PP-5263 as of October 22, 2021) “On measures to further improve the anti-corruption expertise of normative legal acts and their drafts” was adopted. From January 1, 2022, representatives of scientific organizations and universities, as well as individuals - independent experts can conduct scientific and independent anti-corruption expertise of regulatory legal acts and their drafts. The conclusions based on the results of the examination are subject to mandatory consideration by the relevant state bodies and organizations. The Decree also approved the Roadmap for the elimination of corruption factors identified as a result of the anti-corruption examination of regulatory legal acts in the field of construction, healthcare, higher education and public procurement. In addition to drafts, the ministry started conducting anti-corruption expertise of enacted acts. In Y2021, 190 enacted normative acts underwent anti-corruption expertise. Over the next five years, about 25,000 enacted acts are scheduled for anti-corruption expertise. In Y2021, the Ministry of Justice received 2554 draft normative legal acts for review, out of which it conducted legal expertise of 2246 draft normative legal acts (88%), with compulsory anticorruption screening. 308 draft legal acts (12%) returned to initiators without review due to improvement needs within Regulation requirements. 1606 drafts (72%) has received positive conclusions while 640 drafts (28%) received conclusions they are inappropriate. Target has been achieved by 125%.
3. In 2021 provision of public services through electronic channels continued to be the focus of the government in this direction. a) my.gov.uz has been increased the number of e-services from 213 in 2020 to 309 in 2021 (180 in 2019). At the same time, a mobile application for a single portal of public services was launched. Now the population can use services through telephones. In 2021, totally 1 mln applications for public services have been processed. b) Regulation.gov.uz continued to be extensively used by government agencies for public consultations. By the end of 2021, drafts of 11,680 normative acts were discussed on the website, of which 11,577 acts were discussed, 103 acts are under discussion. E-petitions platform (meningfikrim.uz) is operating for citizens to allege their concerns and statements. By the end of 2021, 5109 public appeals went through it, for which 27839 comments were received. 36 appeals are under maintenance, 102 are under examination, 1 is under voting. Numerous other e-participation tools are being utilized by government agencies (jamoatchilik.uz, meningovozim.tashkent.uz) for solving specific tasks. c) Data.gov.uz (besides stat.uz and openbudget.uz) is used by government agencies and citizens as source of open data. By the end of 2021, it contains 13,440 types of open data from 183 different departments and organizations. In addition, according to Presidential Decree No. 4257 of July 2021, all ministries and departments are required to publish a number of internal data related to departmental property and budget expenditures on their public websites. Control over execution is entrusted to the Anti-Corruption Agency, which has the right to initiate disciplinary punishment against the heads of organizations for failure to comply with the decree. d) New national ID system has been operationalized in 2021. Now ID Card (released instead of internal passport) is used as primary identification source for delivering public services together with internal passport, while several digital identification platforms (One ID, ID.uz, State Tax Agency Digital Identity System, UNICONs Digital Identity System) use e-digital signatures as well. e) According to my.gov.uz, the most popular public services in 2021 were Familiarization with the credentials of legal entities and individual entrepreneurs , Filing an application for the placement of a child in a preschool educational institution for individuals; License to carry out international transportation of passengers and goods by road and Issuance of a cadastral passport for legal entities.
4.The media continued to gain watchdog and anticorruption observer role in the country in 2021. Only one informational web resource – gazeta.uz, has published 28 articles and reports on corruption and anticorruption news in 2021. Other resources like kun.uz, podrobno.uz, social bloggers were active in overseeing state activity in this regard, publishing regularly anticorruption reports. In order to strengthen the role of civil society and the media, increase the knowledge of non-governmental organizations, journalists and social activists in combating corruption, the project organized a special training on the topic: “The role of interaction with the public in combating corruption” for NGOs and the media, which was attended by representatives of more 35 NGOs and 25 media outlets. The training specifically focused on the role and interests of groups most vulnerable to corruption, such as women, youth, people with disabilities, the elderly, etc.
5. Overall 56 anticorruption education and outreach events have been organized by PCEAT project, with the participation of 1000 people, including 370 women, 60% of them are representatives of state agencies, with involvement of 20 foreign experts, 10 of them are women. 400 government officials, including 150 women, were trained in 18 training sessions conducted by KPMG and the Project on anti-corruption compliance in government bodies.

1. As to the latest data available at The Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI) project website, Uzbekistan currently ranked 12,50 in Control of Corruption Index that is significant progress compared to 12,02 in previous year and exceeds target for 2019.
2. Ministry of Justice of Uzbekistan (MoJ) conducted legal expertize of 2120 draft normative legal acts in 2019 with compulsory anticorruption screening and 2086 draft legal acts are adopted, and only 90% were approved with or without comments, e.g. with positive conclusion to proceed,others returned to initiators due to significant improvement needs. The declining number of draft legal acts that were rejected for adoption demonstrates improvement in quality of rulemaking and drafting. Target was achieved by 132%. The number of draft legal acts returned in 2019 for revisioning is 203 (725 in 2018, 992 in 2017), which is 10% from total number of draft legal acts submitted for legal expertize (28% in 2018, 31% in 2017).
3. a) my.gov.uz has been become the main government electronic tool that provides access to 180 public services, while 93 services are provided through Public Service Centers only physically. Moreover, almost all public institutions that has websites have special pages operating for rendering relevant public services online. E-auksion, E-Harid and other governmental portals were launched for providing services to business. b) Regulation.gov.uz has been extensively used by government agencies for public consultations. Governments e-petitions platform (meningfikrim.uz) is operating for citizens to allege their concerns and statements. Numerous other e-participation tools are being utilized by government agencies (jamoatchilik.uz, meningovozim.tashkent.uz) for solving specific tasks. c) Data.gov.uz, stat.uz and openbudget.uz are used by government agencies and citizens as source of open data. d) Primary identification sources for delivering public services are (if in-person) internal passport and (if online) several digital identification platforms (One ID, ID.uz, State Tax Agency Digital Identity System, UNICONs Digital Identity System). New national ID system will be operationalised by 2021. National Agency of Project Management is considering the implementation of the single identification interface for users based on the ONE ID digital platform. UNDP is supporting agency in identifying the feasibility of using the biometric data for identifying user. f) Public procurement operations are regulated through several e-service tools like harid.uz, goszakupka.uz, uzex.uz (stock exchange). December 5, 2019, the new Presidential Decree was released to streamline public procurements for strategic state owned enterprises that established special web-portal for huge amount procurements and ensuring transparency and competitiveness. Another critical public service covered in 2019 was Public e-service on enrollment to public kindergartens.
4. Local mass media and information sources continued to report numerous corrupted practice cases detected and investigated by law enforcement throughout a year that raised huge public interest, engagement, discussion and in some cases criticism. While informal information sources like social media championed the criticism, formal mass media were also involved very much in reporting corruption like such web-media sources as kun.uz, podrobno.uz, gazeta.uz, uz.sputniknews.ru (operating from Russia) and others. The bigger public discussion was triggered by the series of publications related to criminal charges against the number of top public officials, including former Chief of Intelligence and General Prosecutor of the country. Several publications covered the arrest of judges, local governance (municipality) heads, police officials. This lead to that the General Prosecutor’s Office decided to open its data by itself and the first time it conducted press-conference in the Agency for Information and Mass Communications of Uzbekistan in June 2019, fully devoted to discussion of corruption status and anticorruption in the country. The last wave of mass media reports on corruption was launched after the latest meeting of the Republican Interagency Commission on combatting corruption hold in late December 2019, when the pervasive state of corruption in Healthcare Industry was revealed by the Commission and the huge amount of damage detected by law enforcement was announced by Commission Head – newly appointed General Prosecutor.
5. Totally twelve capacity building and educational events have been organized by PCEAT project in 2019, with the participation of 960 people, including 420 women, 587 representatives of state agencies and 93 foreign experts, including 40 women. These events promoted a zero-tolerance towards corruption in society and openly discussed corruption-related issues, with the inclusion of various stakeholders. 190 participants and government officials were trained in 2 training workshops, including 45 women: 1) Workshop on implementing the recommendations from the 4th Round of Monitoring of Uzbekistan under the OECD ACN/Istanbul Action Plan, and 2) Training on ‘Anti-Corruption in the Context of the 2030 Agenda’. As a result of the training, participants gained knowledge/skills in a range of topics on anti-corruption, that are in line with the government’s development and anti-corruption priorities. Three study tours were organised, where 38 government officials learned best practices from Norway, Denmark, Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea and OECD (France). The study tours enhanced the knowledge of government officials on how countries with low levels of corruption were able to promote transparency, accountability, efficiency, integrity and anti-corruption.

1. As to the latest data available at The Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI) project website, Uzbekistan currently ranked 14,42 in Control of Corruption Index that is significant progress compared to 12,98 in previous year and exceeds target for 2020.
2. The Ministry of Justice of Uzbekistan (MoJ) conducted legal expertise of 2272 draft normative legal acts in Y2020 out of 2476 received, with compulsory anticorruption screening. 1539 draft legal acts are adopted (68%) with or without comments, others returned to initiators due to improvement needs. The declining number of draft legal acts that were rejected for adoption demonstrates improvement in quality of rulemaking and drafting: the number of draft legal acts returned without legal expertise due to inconsistency with quality requirements in Y2020 is 204 (203 in 2019, 725 in 2018, 992 in 2017), which is 8 % from total number of draft legal acts received for legal expertise (10% in 2019, 28% in 2018, 31% in 2017). Target has been achieved by 133%.
3. Due to pandemic restrictions, provision of public services through electronic channels was the focus of the government in this direction. a) my.gov.uz has been still the main government electronic tool that provides access to 213 public services as at the 2020 (180 in 2019), while around 150 services are provided through Public Service Centers only physically, out of total 700 public services. In 2020, totally 3,5 mln applications for public services have been processed electronically. E-auksion, E-Harid were among governmental portals the most popular for business entities to get access to public procurement. b) Regulation.gov.uz has been extensively used by government agencies for public consultations. Governments e-petitions platform (meningfikrim.uz) is operating for citizens to allege their concerns and statements. Numerous other e-participation tools are being utilized by government agencies (jamoatchilik.uz, meningovozim.tashkent.uz) for solving specific tasks. c) Data.gov.uz, stat.uz and openbudget.uz are used by government agencies and citizens as source of open data. d) Primary identification sources for delivering public services are (if in-person) internal passport and (if online) several digital identification platforms (One ID, ID.uz, State Tax Agency Digital Identity System, UNICONs Digital Identity System). New national ID system will be operationalised by 2021. e) The most popular (critical) public services have been provided in education (kindergartens), customs, health and tax industries. However, the majority of them relates to provision of data and information to customer, while for receiving the complete service the customer needs still physically visit Public Services Centers, Customs and Tax Authorities.
4. The media are becoming a key element of an effective anti-corruption and public oversight system. Several television channels and web resources have become the most popular among the population precisely due to publications on corruption, both at the national and local levels. Anti-corruption activists are gaining even more popularity on social networks and messengers. For instance, the statistics on Integrity (Anticorruption) Awards conducted by Anticorruption Agency jointly with international organizations, including UNDP, shows the growth in the number and relevance of the publications about corruption. UNDP supported the holding of the Integrity Award in nominations related to media anticorruption activities, such as “The Best Journalistic Anticorruption Investigation”, “The Most Active Media in Anticorruption Advocacy”, and “For Anticorruption Activeness in Social Networks (bloggers, groups, channels, etc.). And 49 journalistic investigation works have been accepted for the nomination the Best Journalistic Investigation only. Publications of web-resources Kun.uz, Gazeta.uz, social channels davletov.uz, bakiroo, anticorruption groups in Facebook, not mentioning the formally blocked web-sites, have impacted government’s policy and formed a trend to immediate response and relevant reaction by the government.
5. Despite challenges and restrictions associated with pandemic, PCEAT project managed to host 16 anticorruption education and outreach events in 2020, mostly online, with the participation of around 800 people, including 320 women, 60% of them are representatives of state agencies, with involvement of 20 foreign experts, 10 of them are women. These events (webinars, seminars, round tables, conferences, forums) promoted a knowledge, skills, information sharing in anticorruption among public servicemen, as well as zero-tolerance towards corruption in society and openly discussed corruption-related issues, with the inclusion of various stakeholders. 20 employees of the Ministry of Justice, including 5 women, and 20 employees of the General Prosecutor’s Office have been specifically trained for ISO 37001:2016 “Anti-bribery management system” by SGS Company with certifying their level; 2) 290 government officials, including around 40 women, were trained in 12 training seminars conducted by KPMG Auditing Company with respect to implementation of anticorruption compliance system in public agencies, auditing for compliance and managing conflict of interest in public service. As a result, participants gained knowledge/skills in a range of topics on anti-corruption that are in line with the government’s development and anti-corruption priorities.
